titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

body.p: Grey & chilly day. Long & very interesting letter from Ernest, who is making the most of his opportunities in Salonika. Also, from Harold. Inskip, the Rector of Southport, writes to borrow my "Edinburgh Review" Article. I wrote the following in reply:–

p.hi: Herewith I send the E.R. wh. contains the article wh. you refer to. It is my only copy, so I shall trust you to return it. The Evangelicals sh

consider carefully the actual situation. At present they are in danger of losing all influence on the policy of the Anglican Communion: & that policy is now definitely assuming a character, which will finally be incompatible with their membership of the Anglican Church. It is really time for them to ask themselves very seriously '
?' My own belief is that the most hopeful direction in wh. to make an effort is that wh. w
commit the C. of E. to such a course of action as c

demonstrate her essentially Evangelical (Reformed or Protestant) character. This is the importance in my eyes of that "Exchange of Pulpits" wh. the Evangelical Bps might secure at once if they had but a fraction of the insight and courage wh. mark the Bps of Oxford & Winchester. As it is, they keep silence & do nothing while the Anglican Communion is being organized on principles wh. they cannot really accept, & the Anglican conscience is being 'taught' deliberately on "Catholick" lines. The enclosed may, perhaps, interest you.

body.p: I sent him with this letter a copy of the Correspondence with the B. of L. [Bishop of London] The "Edinburgh Review" was sent to him.
